description:
Though it's sometimes relegated to second or third place among TormÃƒÂ©'s best albums of the '50s (behind Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mel TormÃƒÂ© and the Marty Paich Dek-TetteÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ and Ã¢â‚¬Å“It's a Blue WorldÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½), it's difficult to hear how Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mel TormÃƒÂ© Sings Fred AstaireÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ can't be the best album of his entire career. 

There's a mix of enthusiasm and sophisticated ease here that makes this one of Torme's finest recordings. He's aided by Marty Paich's lively, brassy arrangements and an excellent studio band with trumpeter Pete Condoli and saxophonists Herb Geller and Jack Montrose.

A collection of perfect hard-swinging pop with a few ballads thrown in for good measure makes Sings Fred Astaire a masterpiece, one of the best up-tempo vocal albums ever recorded.
